div.head: JinnTap
div.p: Edit TEI XML documents using a rich text editor. JinnTap preserves the structure of the XML in the editor. There's no need for complex transformation steps from TEI to HTML and back. The representation of the document in the editor corresponds directly to the XML. TEI elements are converted to HTML custom elements, preserving all attributes and structural features.

While it is very difficult to create a completely generic editor covering the entire complexity of TEI, JinnTap tries to be as customizable as possible. To work properly in a WYSIWYMWhat you see is what you mean context, the editor needs to be strict with respect to the underlying schema. Many elements in TEI are ambiguous with respect to their block or inline nature, i.e. they can appear either way. However, the editor has a clear distinction between block and inline content. Therefore JinnTap uses its own schema to define what is allowed in which position. It extends the schema used by the underlying editor (ProseMirror) to configure additional features like toolbar buttons, keyboard shortcuts etc. and is written in JSON.
Out of the box, the default schema supports:

item.p: block level elements like headings, paragraphs, lists
elements for inline formatting like hi, title
semantic markup for people, organizations, places, terms

div.head: How to edit
div.p: The default starting point for editing is always a paragraph. Use the toolbar buttons to transform it into a heading or another type of block. Note that – according to the gods of TEI – not all elements are allowed at any position. A head may only appear at the start of a division, not after a paragraph. This is where TEI differs from HTML.

item.p: a block will be deleted if you press backspace or delete inside an otherwise empty block.
pressing tab will create a nested list below the current one
shift-tab moves the list item one level up. If it is already at the top level, it will be transformed into a normal paragraph
TEI lists may start with a heading. You can transform the first list item into a head by placing the cursor inside the item and choosing Head from the toolbar.
to enter an en dash (–), use two hyphens, to create an mdash (—), type three hyphens

div.p: Apply inline markup by selecting some text and pressing a corresponding button. Note that those buttons are toggles, i.e. pressing again will remove the inline markup.

div.head: Changing attributes
div.p: Whenever you move around the document, you'll see how the right-hand panel of the editor changes, showing a form with different fields. Those are the attributes which can be applied to the current element. You can change them any time and the attributes of the element will change accordingly.

For example, if you marked something as bold text, you can change it later to underline by placing the cursor inside the element and choosing underline from the dropdown. Don't forget to click the apply button though.

To change the attributes of a node which is an ancestor of the node the cursor is currently in, use the breadcrumbs navigation bar on the upper right of the editor. This shows all the ancestor nodes down to the currently active node. Clicking on any of the breadcrumb links will select the corresponding node and the attribute panel will show the attributes assigned to this node.

div.head: Divisions
div.p: Use the Division toolbar button to create a div. The new division will always be a child of the division you are currently in. To move the division one level up, position the cursor anywhere inside it, then use the breadcrumb navigation bar to select the division. Next, click on the move block up button in the toolbar.

You may also move other block-level nodes one level up by following the same procedure. However, please note that moving up a block, which has a following block within the same parent, will split the division.

div.head: Semantic annotations
div.p: JinnTap has extended support for semantic annotation, drawing on external registers to identify entities like people, places, organizations or terms. To mark up a person appearing in the text, say: Karl Marx, select the name and press the Person toolbar button. The attributes panel to the right will show you a search panel, which is connected to the registered registry. Find the correct person in the list and click on the link button to the left of the entry. This copies the ID of the person from the registry into the key form field.

Note that selecting an entry from the registry will automatically apply the attribute, so if this is your only change, you don't have to press the apply-all button manually. After selecting, you should also see some additional information about the entity displayed at the very top of the attribute panel.

noteGrp.note: In more technical terms, the editor distinguishes between nodes and marks: while nodes are mostly block-level elements (with some exceptions), marks are lightweight markers attached to a piece of text.
